data.title: Royal Family news: Princess Delphine at first official ceremony alongside King Albert
data.meta_description: PRINCESS Delphine of Belgium appeared at a public official ceremony alongside her father King Albert II and his wife Queen Paola for the first time on Thursday.
data.text:
Princess Delphine among Belgian royals attending Brussels event

Belgium’s entire Royal Family were present at the Church of Our Lady of Laeken on Thursday morning for the annual mass ceremony held in memory of their lost loved ones. The sombre occasion marked the first time King Albert II, Queen Paola and Princess Delphine have appeared together in public.

Those in attendance at the Notre-Dame de Laeken church included King Philippe, 61 – the eldest child of King Albert II – and his wife Queen Mathilde, 49.

They joined King Albert, 87, and Queen Paola, 84, to sit in the front row.

King Phillippe’s sister, Princess Astrid and her husband, Archduke Lorenz, also sat alongside them for the service.

In the second row sat King Phillippe’s younger brother Prince Laurent and his wife, Princess Claire.

Princess Lea - widow of Prince Alexander, son of King Leopold III and Lilian Baels – also attended the mass, alongside Princess Delphine, 53, and her husband James O'Hare.

The location of the service is particularly poignant as its crypt is where members of the Royal Family are buried.

Normally the service that commemorates the lives of deceased members of royalty is attended by the most senior members of the Belgian Royal Family.

The tradition of paying tribute to the deceased members of the monarchy dates back to February 17, 1935.

At this time, a mass was held to commemorate the death of King Albert I, who had died a year earlier at Marche-les-Dames.

Following the death of Queen Astrid on August 29, 1935, it was decided tribute would be paid to all the deceased members of the Royal Family on February 17.

Due to COVID-19 measures last year, the traditional mass ceremony could not take place.

Instead, members of the Royal Family visited the Royal Crypt at different times.

2022’s offering marked the first time the whole family has come together in public.

Princess Delphine was officially recognised as the daughter of King Albert II in 2020, after being born out of wedlock.

The Princess won her battle in court to be officially recognised as his child and was reconciled with her father.

The King confirmed her parenthood on January 27, 2020 in a press release, and Delphine was recognized as a princess of Belgium and granted the new surname of Saxe-Coburg in October 2020.

Last summer, Princess Delphine attended the National Day parade but her father Albert and his wife Queen Paola were not present.

After Thursday’s ceremony, members of the Royal Family took a brief moment to greet some royal watchers who had gathered outside.

Some of the royals were presented with flowers and gifts.

Among the people being remembered at the service was likely the Grand Duke Jean of Luxembourg, who died in April 2019.

He was very close to the Royal Family of Belgium, being the brother-in-law of King Albert.
